revision.text: {{also|X-mas}} ==English== [[Image:PostcardIBringYouAMerryXmas1910.jpg|thumb|1910 postcard]] {{wikipedia}} ===Alternative forms=== * {{l|en|X-mas}} * {{l|en|Xtmas}} {{qualifier|archaic}} ===Etymology=== Attested in this form since 1755, and preceded by earlier forms such as {{m|en|X'temmas}} (1551) and {{inh|en|ang|Χp̃es mæssa}} (1100), from {{m|ang|Cristes mæsse}}, with abbreviation of {{m|ang|Cristes}} by the symbol {{m|en|X}}, {{obor|en|grc|Χ|pos=letter [[chi]]|nocap=y}}, from {{m|grc|Χριστός||[[Christ]]}}. Surface analysis {{suffix|en|X|mas|t1=Christ|t2=holiday}}. In popular use since late 19th century. See [[w:Xmas|Wikipedia]] for more information. ===Pronunciation=== Pronounced either as {{m|en|Christmas}} or as {{m|en|X}}+{{m|en|-mas}}: * {{enPR|krĭs'məs|ĕks'məs}}, {{IPA|en|/ˈkɹɪs.məs/|/ˈɛks.məs/}} * {{audio|en|LL-Q1860 (eng)-Vealhurl-Xmas.wav|Audio (UK)}} * {{rhymes|en|ɪsməs|q1=homophone of Christmas|s=2}} * {{hmp|en|Christmas}} ===Noun=== {{en-noun}} # {{lb|en|informal}} {{abbreviation of|en|Christmas}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=c. 1755 |author=Bernard Ward |title=History of St. Edmund's college, Old Hall |page=303 |pageurl=http://books.google.com/books?id=kMpBAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA303 |passage=In ye '''Xmas''' and Whitsuntide Vacations, ye Scholars study at a rate of an hour and a Quarter each day & all yt go home have proportionable Tasks set them... }} #* {{quote-journal |en |date=1801-12-31 |first=Samuel |last=Coleridge |authorlink=Samuel Coleridge |contribution=letter to R. Southey |year_published=1894 |month_published=January |title=Ten Letters from Coleridge to Southey |magazine=The Atlantic Monthly |volume=73 |issue=435 |page=66 |pageurl=http://books.google.com/books?id=12oAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA66 |passage=On '''Xmas''' Day I breakfasted with Davy, with the intention of dining with you... }} #* {{quote-book |en |date=1811-09-09 |first=George Gordon |last=Byron |authorlink=Lord Byron |chapter=To the Hon. Augusta Leigh |title=The Works of Lord Byron |volume=9 |year_published=1898 |publisher=John Murray |location=London |editor=Prothero, Rowland E. |page=31 |pageurl=http://books.google.com/books?id=QmERAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA31&dq=Xmas |passage={{...}}but if you won't come here before '''Xmas''', I very much fear we shall not meet ''here'' at all{{...}} }} #* {{quote-book |en |date=1861-06-23 |first=Charles |last=Dickens |authorlink=Charles Dickens |contribution=letter to Wilkie Collins |year_published=1892 |title=Letters of Charles Dickens to Wilkie Collins |editor=Hutton, Laurence |publisher=Harper & Brothers |location=New York |page=100 |pageurl=http://books.google.com/books?id=CXtaAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA100 |passage=My dear Wilkie,—we will arrange our '''Xmas''' No., please God, under the shade of the Oak Trees. }} #* {{quote-book |en |date=1864-06-10 |first=Lewis |last=Carroll |authorlink=Lewis Caroll |title=The Letters of Lewis Carroll |volume=1 |editor=Cohen, Morton N. |publisher=Macmillan |location=London |year_published=1979 |page=65 |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9IwrAQAAIAAJ |passage=I should be very glad if you could help me in fixing on a name for my fairy-tale, which Mr. Tenniel (in consequence of your kind introduction) is now illustrating for me, and which I hope to get published before '''Xmas'''. }} #* {{quote-journal |en |date=1879-11-13 |title=Our London Letter |author=W. F. C. |magazine=The American Stationer |volume=7 |issue=46 |page=2 |pageurl=http://books.google.com/books?id=O2JYAAAAYAAJ&pg=RA3-PA82&dq=Xmas |passage=A '''Xmas''' card is a pleasant memento of a season of good will and kindly sentiment. It is a reminiscence of '''Xmas''' time. With '''Xmas''' we associate happy gatherings of friends, wintry skies without and cheerful hearths within, ice and snow to be kept in subjugation by warmth of disposition and genial affection. The '''Xmas''' cards ought to embody such traits, physical and mental. }} #* {{quote-journal |en |date=1885-12-10 |title=Our '''Xmas''' at Windsor |magazine=[[w:Life (magazine)|Life]] |volume=6 |issue=154 |first=Carlyle |last=Smith |location=New York |page=338 |pageurl=http://books.google.com/books?id=pZJGAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA338&dq=Xmas |passage={{...}}as well as give the Imperial spree a notice next to reading matter in the '''Xmas''' issue{{...}} }} #* {{quote-journal |en |year=1897 |month=December |magazine=The American Monthly Illustrated Review of Reviews |title=A '''Xmas''' gift for one dollar ''[advertisement]'' |author=Standard American Publishing Co. |volume=16 |issue=95 |page=49 |pageurl=http://books.google.com/books?id=EtYeQue3_UsC&pg=RA1-PA49&dq=Xmas }} #* {{quote-book |en |date=1913-11-18 |first=C. S. |last=Lewis |authorlink=C. S. Lewis |title=The Collected Letters of C.S. Lewis: Family Letters, 1905-1931 |editor=Hooper, Walter |publisher=HarperCollins |location=New York |year_published=2004 |isbn=9780060727635 |page=41 |pageurl=http://books.google.com/books?id=eOxfuF6BQ0gC&pg=PA41&dq=Xmas |passage=Don't let us spoil the '''Xmas''' holidays by a chore as colossal as it is disagreeable, and as disagreeable as it is unnecessary. }} ====Usage notes==== Discouraged in formal usage, and as of late 20th century considered disrespectful by some Christians, due to the absence of the word {{m|en|Christ}}.
